nodes.bodyText:
I don't understand this classification.
I'd say the discovery protocols fall into two broad categories:

the generic ones (TCPPING and UDPPING) which should work on most network and don't rely on external services
those that rely on some external source for storing/retrieving topology information (DNS, Kubernetes, S3, JDBC, Gossip, etc)
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,16 @@
+[id='cluster_discovery-{context}']
+= Cluster Discovery Protocols
+{brandname} supports different protocols that allow nodes to automatically find each other on the network and form clusters.
+
+{brandname} can use the following discovery mechanisms:
+
+* Generic discovery protocols (`TCPPING` and `TCPGOSSIP`)
+* JGroups PING protocols (`KUBE_PING` and `DNS_PING`)

nodes.bodyText:
Thanks, that makes a lot more sense.
@tristantarrant I noticed there is no example of UDPPING in our docs. Do you mean PING instead? If so should we include an example of PING alongside the others?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,16 @@

+
+{brandname} can use the following discovery mechanisms:
+
+* Generic discovery protocols (`TCPPING` and `TCPGOSSIP`)
+* JGroups PING protocols (`KUBE_PING` and `DNS_PING`)

not sure why step 1 (locate) & 2 (view xml) are required. Reading this it seems mandatory to open the XML file.
IMO, You can just tell where the XML is.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,51 @@
+[id='jgroups_getting_started-{context}']
+= Getting Started with Default Stacks
+{brandname} uses JGroups protocol stacks so nodes can send each other messages on dedicated cluster channels.
+
+{brandname} provides preconfigured JGroups stacks for `UDP` and `TCP` protocols.
+You can use these default stacks as a starting point for building custom cluster transport configuration that is optimized for your network requirements.
+
+.Procedure
+
+. Locate the default JGroups stacks in the `default-configs` directory inside the `infinispan-core-{ispn_version}.jar` file.

nodes.bodyText: is this true? You don't need stack.position when used with COMBINE. I'm not expecting it to reset everything :)
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,37 @@
+[id='jgroups_inheritance_attributes-{context}']
+= Inheritance Attributes
+When you extend a JGroups stack, inheritance attributes let you adjust protocols and properties in the stack you are extending.
+
+* `stack.combine` uses the following values to extends JGroups stacks:
++
+[%header,cols="1,2"]
+|===
+
+| Value
+| Description
+
+| `COMBINE`
+| Overrides protocol properties.
+
+| `REPLACE`
+| Replaces protocols.
+
+| `INSERT_AFTER`
+| Adds a protocol into the stack after another protocol.
+Does not affect the protocol that you specify as the insertion point.
+
+Protocols in JGroups stacks affect each other based on their location in the stack.
+For example, you should put a protocol such as `NAKACK2` after the `SYM_ENCRYPT` or `ASYM_ENCRYPT` protocol so that `NAKACK2` is secured.
+
+| `INSERT_BEFORE`
+| Inserts a protocols into the stack before another protocol.
+Affects the protocol that you specify as the insertion point.
+
+| `REMOVE`
+| Removes protocols from the stack.
+
+|===
+
+* `stack.position` specifies protocols to modify.
+If you do not specify `stack.position`, {brandname} modifies the corresponding protocol in the stack.
+This resets all protocol attributes that you do not specify to default values.

nodes.bodyText: yeah, maybe this doesn't make sense. I'll remove. thanks!
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,37 @@
+[id='jgroups_inheritance_attributes-{context}']
+= Inheritance Attributes
+When you extend a JGroups stack, inheritance attributes let you adjust protocols and properties in the stack you are extending.
+
+* `stack.combine` uses the following values to extends JGroups stacks:
++
+[%header,cols="1,2"]
+|===
+
+| Value
+| Description
+
+| `COMBINE`
+| Overrides protocol properties.
+
+| `REPLACE`
+| Replaces protocols.
+
+| `INSERT_AFTER`
+| Adds a protocol into the stack after another protocol.
+Does not affect the protocol that you specify as the insertion point.
+
+Protocols in JGroups stacks affect each other based on their location in the stack.
+For example, you should put a protocol such as `NAKACK2` after the `SYM_ENCRYPT` or `ASYM_ENCRYPT` protocol so that `NAKACK2` is secured.
+
+| `INSERT_BEFORE`
+| Inserts a protocols into the stack before another protocol.
+Affects the protocol that you specify as the insertion point.
+
+| `REMOVE`
+| Removes protocols from the stack.
+
+|===
+
+* `stack.position` specifies protocols to modify.
+If you do not specify `stack.position`, {brandname} modifies the corresponding protocol in the stack.
+This resets all protocol attributes that you do not specify to default values.

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,16 @@
+[id='cluster_discovery-{context}']
+= Cluster Discovery Protocols
+{brandname} supports different protocols that allow nodes to automatically find each other on the network and form clusters.
+
+There are two types of discovery mechanisms that {brandname} can use:
+
+* Generic discovery protocols that work on most networks and do not rely on external services.
+* Discovery protocols that rely on external services to store and retrieve topology information for {brandname} clusters. +
+For instance the JDBC_PING protocol uses a shared database where nodes write their IP addresses.
+
+[NOTE]
+====
+Running {brandname} on hosted platforms requires using discovery mechanisms that are adapted to network constraints that individual cloud providers impose.
+====
+
+* link:http://www.jgroups.org/manual/html/protlist.html#DiscoveryProtocols[JGroups Discovery Protocols]

nodes.bodyText: fixed
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,16 @@
+[id='cluster_discovery-{context}']
+= Cluster Discovery Protocols
+{brandname} supports different protocols that allow nodes to automatically find each other on the network and form clusters.
+
+There are two types of discovery mechanisms that {brandname} can use:
+
+* Generic discovery protocols that work on most networks and do not rely on external services.
+* Discovery protocols that rely on external services to store and retrieve topology information for {brandname} clusters. +
+For instance the JDBC_PING protocol uses a shared database where nodes write their IP addresses.
+
+[NOTE]
+====
+Running {brandname} on hosted platforms requires using discovery mechanisms that are adapted to network constraints that individual cloud providers impose.
+====
+
+* link:http://www.jgroups.org/manual/html/protlist.html#DiscoveryProtocols[JGroups Discovery Protocols]

JGroups TCPPING needs update:
http://jgroups.org/manual4/index.html#TCPPING_Prot
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -1,11 +1,8 @@
+[id='discovery_tcpping-{context}']
 = TCPPING
-`TCPPING` is a generic JGroups discovery mechanism that uses a static list of IP
-addresses for cluster members.
+TCPPING is a generic JGroups discovery mechanism that uses a list of static addresses for cluster members.
 
-To use `TCPPING`, you must add the list of static IP addresses to the JGroups
-configuration file for each {brandname} node. However, the drawback to
-`TCPPING` is that it does not allow nodes to dynamically join {brandname}
-clusters.
+With TCPPING, you manually specify the IP address or hostname of each node in the {brandname} cluster as part of the JGroups stack, rather letting nodes discover each other dynamically.
 
 .TCPPING configuration example
 [source,xml,options="nowrap",subs=attributes+]

nodes.bodyText:
I'm overthinking again 😨
this section is fine for embedded. But for the server, it requires custom jars to be placed in server/lib: the jgroups-google jar and manually find its dependencies. (same for azure & native_s3)
this isn't a trivial task and the server docs make it look too easy. I'm not sure how to proceed here:

Remove those discovery protocols from server docs?
something else?

nodes.bodyText: Is JDBC_PING a good example here? It seems one of the more niche discovery protocols. How about DNS_PING? That's what we use in kubernetes/openshfit.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,23 @@
+[id='cluster_discovery-{context}']
+= Cluster Discovery Protocols
+{brandname} supports different protocols that allow nodes to automatically find each other on the network and form clusters.
+
+There are two types of discovery mechanisms that {brandname} can use:
+
+* Generic discovery protocols that work on most networks and do not rely on external services.
+* Discovery protocols that rely on external services to store and retrieve topology information for {brandname} clusters. +
+For instance the JDBC_PING protocol uses a shared database where nodes write their IP addresses.

nodes.bodyText:
This will not modify the timout alone!
It will replace the protocol - so nothing is used from the original settings
it is exactly this setting which is used
(for VERIFY_SUSPECT there is not really a setting in defaults but it is worth to mention)
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,85 @@
+[id='using_jgroups_inheritance-{context}']
+= Customizing JGroups Stacks
+Adjust and tune properties to create a cluster transport configuration that works for your network requirements.
+
+{brandname} provides attributes that let you extend the default JGroups stacks for easier configuration.
+You can inherit properties from the default stacks while combining, removing, and replacing other properties.
+
+.Procedure
+
+. Create a new JGroups stack declaration in your `infinispan.xml` file.
++
+[source,xml,options="nowrap",subs=attributes+]
+----
+<infinispan>
+  <jgroups>
+    <stack name="my-stack"> <1>
+    </stack>
+  </jgroups>
+</infinispan>
+----
++
+<1> Creates a custom JGroups stack named "my-stack".
++
+. Add the `extends` attribute and specify a JGroups stack to inherit properties from.
++
+[source,xml,options="nowrap",subs=attributes+]
+----
+<infinispan>
+  <jgroups>
+    <stack name="my-stack" extends="tcp"> <1>
+    </stack>
+  </jgroups>
+</infinispan>
+----
++
+<1> Inherits from the default TCP stack.
++
+. Use the `stack.combine` attribute to modify properties for protocols configured in the inherited stack.
+. Use the `stack.position` attribute to define the location for your custom stack.
++
+For example, you might evaluate using a Gossip router and symmetric encryption with the default TCP stack as follows:
++
+[source,xml,options="nowrap",subs=attributes+]
+----
+include::config_examples/config_jgroups_extends.xml[]
+----
++
+<1> Uses the `TCPGOSSIP` protocol as the discovery mechanism instead of `MPING`.
+<2> Removes the `FD_SOCK` protocol from the stack.
+<3> Modifies the timeout value for the `VERIFY_SUSPECT` protocol.

nodes.bodyText:
this is false. it only modifies the timeout.
you can verify it by creating a stack like this
<jgroups>
	<stack name="my-stack" extends="tcp">
		<TCP bind_port="8888" enable_diagnostics="true"/>
	</stack>
</jgroups>

and using probe you can check the TCP attributes and check they didn't change.

With default tcp or udp configuration which uses multicast. Other settings might not discover nodes automatically.
Also the netword need to allow mcast

nodes.bodyText:
We should mention that port-offset use in production is not recommended.
Consider that it might change only the infinispan ports (8.0) and the jgroups bind-port if ${jgroups.bind.port} is used in config (8.1.1) but FD_SOCK port is still random by default!
So -o is not always reliable and should be avoided in prod
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -1,25 +1,25 @@
 [id='verify_cluster_discovery-{context}']
-= Verifying {brandname} Cluster Discovery
-{brandname} servers running on the same network discover each other with the
-`MPING` protocol and automatically form clusters. This procedure demonstrates
-that capability with two locally running {brandname} server instances.
+= Verifying Cluster Views
+{brandname} nodes on the same network automatically discover each other and form clusters.
+
+Complete this procedure to observe cluster discovery with the `MPING` protocol in the default `TCP` stack with locally running {brandname} Server instances.
+If you want to adjust cluster transport for custom network requirements, see the documentation for setting up {brandname} clusters.
 
 .Prerequisites
 
-Start a locally running {brandname} server instance.
+Have one instance of {brandname} Server running.
 
 .Procedure
 
-. Create a new {brandname} server instance.
-.. Open a terminal in `{server_home}`.
-.. Copy the root directory to `server2`.
+. Open a terminal in `{server_home}`.
+. Copy the root directory to `server2`.
 +
 [source,options="nowrap",subs=attributes+]
 ----
 $ cp -r server server2
 ----
 +
-. Specify a port offset and the location of the `server2` root directory.

@@ -0,0 +1,57 @@
+[id='jgroups_getting_started-{context}']
+= Getting Started with Default Stacks
+{brandname} uses JGroups protocol stacks so nodes can send each other messages on dedicated cluster channels.
+
+{brandname} provides preconfigured JGroups stacks for `UDP` and `TCP` protocols.
+You can use these default stacks as a starting point for building custom cluster transport configuration that is optimized for your network requirements.
+
+.Procedure
+
+. Locate the default JGroups stacks, `default-jgroups-*.xml`, in the `default-configs` directory inside the `infinispan-core-{ispn_version}.jar` file.

nodes.bodyText: Hint: that will only work if the infinispan.xml contains the transport expression stack=${infinispan.cluster.stack:XXX}
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,57 @@
+[id='jgroups_getting_started-{context}']
+= Getting Started with Default Stacks
+{brandname} uses JGroups protocol stacks so nodes can send each other messages on dedicated cluster channels.
+
+{brandname} provides preconfigured JGroups stacks for `UDP` and `TCP` protocols.
+You can use these default stacks as a starting point for building custom cluster transport configuration that is optimized for your network requirements.
+
+.Procedure
+
+. Locate the default JGroups stacks, `default-jgroups-*.xml`, in the `default-configs` directory inside the `infinispan-core-{ispn_version}.jar` file.
+ifdef::server_mode[]
++
+The `jar` file is in the `{server_home}/lib` directory.
++
+endif::server_mode[]
+. Do one of the following:
+
+* Use the `stack` attribute in your `infinispan.xml` file.
++
+[source,xml,options="nowrap",subs=attributes+]
+----
+include::config_examples/config_transport_stack.xml[]
+----
+<1> Uses `default-jgroups-udp.xml` for cluster transport.
+
+ifdef::embedded_mode[]
+* Use the `addProperty()` method to set the JGroups stack file:
++
+[source,java]
+----
+include::code_examples/ConfigureTransportDefault.java[]
+----
+<1> Uses the `default-jgroups-udp.xml` stack for cluster transport.
+endif::embedded_mode[]
+
+ifdef::server_mode[]
+* Use the `cluster-stack` argument when you start the server:
++
+[source,options="nowrap",subs=attributes+]
+----
+$ bin/server.sh --cluster-stack=udp

nodes.bodyText: Is that correct? I thought --cluster-stack works for any of the default stacks.

nodes.bodyText:
The Bootstrap class will check --cluster-stack and add a property Server.INFINISPAN_CLUSTER_STACK -> infinispan.cluster.stack.
So it woll replace the name of the stack udp/tcp or what ever customized stack you have in config when started
IF and only if the infinispan.xmk include the expression with that name, if you change the expression or remove it it will have no effect!

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,30 @@
+[id='using_jgroups_system_properties-{context}']
+= Using JGroups System Properties
+Pass system properties to {brandname} at startup to tune cluster transport.
+
+.Procedure
+
+* Use `-D<property-name>=<property-value>` arguments to set JGroups system properties as required.
+
+For example, set a custom bind port and IP address as follows:
+
+ifdef::embedded_mode[]
+[source,options="nowrap",subs=attributes+]
+----
+$ java -cp ... -Djgroups.bind.port=1234 -Djgroups.bind.address=192.0.2.0
+----
+
+[NOTE]
+====
+When you embed {brandname} clusters in clustered {wildflybrandname} applications, JGroups system properties can clash or override each other.
+
+For example, you do not set a unique bind address for either your {brandname} cluster or your {wildflybrandname} application.
+In this case both {brandname} and your {wildflybrandname} application use the JGroups default property and attempt to form clusters using the same bind address.
+====
+endif::embedded_mode[]
+ifdef::server_mode[]
+[source,options="nowrap",subs=attributes+]
+----
+$ bin/server.sh -Djgroups.bind.port=1234 -Djgroups.bind.address=192.0.2.0

nodes.bodyText: Will address this in separate Jira as discussed.
